General Changes

  • Spells that were very rarely used were improved.

  • Spells that prevent creatures from acting in combat were made weaker.

  • Healing spells are stronger.

  • Summoning spells always only summon one creature.

  • Many summoned creatures or barriers can now be destroyed by damage.

  • Descriptions are formatted to be easy to read, and the more confusing spells were redesigned.

  • Cantrips can be swapped at long rest by prepared spellcasters, and cantrips are not inherently separate from spells in the rules.

  • Spells generally follow certain conventions, such as spell effects triggering on the turn of the caster where possible.

  • Spells that provided a buff to a target other than the caster can now typically affect more creatures on upcast.

  • Rituals now take 1 minute to cast if the base spell takes 1 action, and they take 10 minutes if the base spell takes 1 minute.

  • Illusions often follow new Illusion rules, which require the caster to make a spellcasting ability check to make the illusion convincing vs. a target's passive perception.

  • Spells that recorded a certain number of words now record a certain length of time.

  • In baseline 5e, the worst light armor is @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-equipment.Item.jSi9ralAm7FzUQbH]{padded armor}, and it appears as we feature it here, except that it imposes disadvantage on stealth checks. This made no sense to us, as other armor that includes padded layers did not impose this disadvantage. However, by removing the disadvantage, we made padded just as good as leather armor. However, because we wanted to remove studded leather armor, we simply gave leather armor the statistics that studded leather armor used to have (with a slight cost decrease).

  • If you are using other 5e sources that reference 'leather armor', give it the statistics of @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-equipment.Item.0Kmj7Hk25ZyGURMI]{leather armor} as we list it here. They are identical. If other sources list 'leather armor', use the statistics of padded armor here. For example, if you create a character at level 1 that starts with leather armor, then that character should start with padded armor instead.

Removed studded leather and ring mail.

  • Studded Leather armor was the best kind of light armor in baseline 5e. The problem is, there's no reason why studs on leather armor would be very useful, and there's no historical precedence for their use. It's likely that studded leather was created as fantasy armor as a misunderstanding of brigandine, which has metal plates beneath leather riveted in place, which on the outside would look like studded leather armor. Conversely, padded armor in 5e was barely in use, but realistically it would be used by most poor soldiers and beginning adventurers rather than leather. We shuffled things around.

  • Ring Mail is also a fictional armor likely born of misinterpretation. It is supposed to consist of rings fixed to a leather layers, but the rings are not linked together. This was likely fabricated based on medieval depictions of chain mail, which, due to artistic style choices (or artistic incompetence) were often depicted with the chain links drawn as disconnected circles on top of leather coats, rather than as an interconnected mesh. However, these historical depictions were meant to depict chain mail over a leather or cloth padding. Since we, as designers and players of 5e have never seen a character wear ring mail, we removed it entirely. Its only function was as starting armor for characters with low strength and dexterity, and ring mail isn't even listed as a starting armor for anyone. In practice we never saw it used, so we didn't replace it.

We also removed many magical versions of armor. There was no point to having +1 padded armor when you could have leather armor, so we pared down the list of magic armor to only the types you would actually want to make or buy.

Overview

Rather than picking a 'race' and a 'background' as in baseline 5e rules, you now pick an 'ancestry' and a background.

@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-rules.JournalEntry.xu7KkQUPMqoEsg19]{Ancestries and Backgrounds} are roughly the same power level as the old race and background system, so you can use our system alongside players using the old system (but you cannot mix and match between the two systems).

There are no ability score improvements linked to ancestry or background. All Elkan 5e methods of ability score generation include extra points by default, resulting in the same totals.

Now you can play a militant dwarf or a maritime kobold, mixing and matching background elements into your character to represent your setting's cultures or your character's unique upbringing.

Combat

  • &reference[Opportunity Attacks]{Attacks of Opportunity} now trigger on any voluntary movement moving away from a creature, rather than just movement that moves outside of a weapon's range. They also trigger on a spellcaster casting a spell with a casting time of 1 action.

  • Dual Wielding: If you are holding two weapons, then you make an additional off-hand attack with your second weapon whenever you take the Attack action. However, if you do not have the @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class-features.Item.ipFfwmfAjjuNXaru]{Two-Weapon Fighting Style}, then you attack with disadvantage on this off-hand attack.

  • &reference[ready]{Readying Actions} no longer requires setting a specific trigger. Readying a bonus action ability now costs a bonus action instead of an action.

  • Switching Weapons: Attackers can switch weapons either as an action or at the start of the attack action.

  • &reference[thrown]{Thrown Weapons} make attacks as ranged weapons when used at range.

  • The rule for casting multiple spells in a turn is this: you can only expend one spell slot per turn. If you ready a spell, that counts as a spell you cast on the turn you begin to ready it.

  • Thunder damage is renamed to &reference[thunder] damage.

Conditions

  • New conditions include &Reference[dazed], &Reference[goaded], &Reference[silenced], &Reference[siphoned], &Reference[weakened].

  • Some spell and ability effects are standardized as conditions: &Reference[confused], &Reference[drained], &Reference[hasted], &Reference[slowed].

  • Some game rules now explicitly count as conditions, including &Reference[concentration], &Reference[cover], &Reference[surprise].

  • &Reference[ObscuredLightly] and &Reference[ObscuredHeavily] have been overhauled to be self-contained as conditions.

  • A &Reference[blinded] creature's speed is halved.

  • &Reference[Deafened] imposes disadvantage on dexterity saves.

  • &Reference[Exhaustion] imposes a -2 penalty to attack rolls, skill checks, saving throws, and the creature's spellcasting saving throw DC, up to -10. At 6 levels, it's lethal.

  • A &Reference[frightened] creature can approach the source of their fear if they end their turn further away.

  • &Reference[Grappled] has been fully reworked, and there are size benefits for the larger and smaller creature in a grapple. Grapples can be used to hang onto larger creatures.

  • The &Reference[paralyzed], &Reference[petrified], &Reference[stunned], and &Reference[unconscious] conditions are all explicitly subsets of the &Reference[incapacitated] condition, which now reduces your speed to 0. Because we rewrote @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-spells.Item.uF02LB10QFatPuIx]{Hideous Laughter}, the only effect in 5e's srd to incapacitate you without reducing your speed to 0, this should be unnoticeable.

  • Clarified the &Reference[invisible] condition.

  • &Reference[Restrained] creatures can no longer use somatic components of spells.

  • &Reference[Slowed] now imposes disadvantage on attacks instead of reducing them to one attack a round, since some creatures only had one attack.

  • &Reference[Surprise] reduces initiative by 20, rather than preventing the creature's first turn. There's also some rules for triggering surprise.

Spellcasting

  • The rule for casting multiple spells in a turn is now the following: Spellcasters can only cast one spell of 1st level or higher in a turn. The exception is spells that have a casting time of 1 reaction

  • A spellcaster must have be able to see their target, or see the center of an area of effect spell they are casting. You do not necessarily need to have an unobstructed path to the target. The exceptions are spell attacks, spells that target the self or a creature you are touching, or spells that activate on an attack like a smite spell.

  • All spellcasters can now use ritual casting.

  • A spellcaster doesn't need to have an empty hand for somatic or material components.

  • There are specific rules to determine an illusion's effectiveness.

  • Curses have general rules.

  • Scrolls are overhauled. They count towards your one spell per turn, and use your spellcasting attack or DC if they're a spell from your class, or use DC 13 if not. They only require a check to use if not on your spell list, and are not consumed if the user fails to cast them.

  • There are also rules for crafting scrolls with @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-equipment.Item.PSBsNmH0WWBmwTMY]{Calligraphy Tools}.

Other

@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.FZlduxFccJSD9Z3I]{Devotion} paladins were renamed to Paragons, are very similar to the original, but have an ability to provide temp hit points instead of turning creatures, and they have bonuses to saves instead of a permanent @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-spells.Item.cwMTnqjwjFYeJtSR]{protection from good and evil}.

@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class.Item.t9qEzMyJh0kg5Djk]{Ranger}

The ranger has been nearly completely redesigned. We wanted to keep the core identity of the ranger at first, but found that they didn't have any features that were any good in the core class. The main damage dealing feature seemed to be the Hunter's Mark spell, which did not increase in damage at higher levels. After about level 5, there was very little to look forward to.

We've improved every single ability, including adding @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class-features.Item.cdMdQLgUef3DBJXm]{a new level 20 feature}.

We also added altered versions of the @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class-features.Item.KppgVw5ML3BigbT3]{Tireless} and @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class-features.Item.S1yVCHJ9Nxz0bHbo]{Precise Hunter} features from the 2024 ruleset at levels 15 and 17.

Rangers now get &Reference[Survival] as a free skill and three others, instead of just three skills. They also gain expertise at level 2.

Favored Enemy was removed and the language it granted made part of the core level 1 proficiencies.

@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class-features.Item.MVuFoUWCqmZ6I4mA]{Natural Explorer} was pared down, and the ability to ignore nonmagical difficult terrain added.

The @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class-features.Item.HPrjgPXLsDRBbfsD]{Mark for Death} ability mimics the Hunter's Mark spell, but does not require concentration, which means it doesn't compete with any of the ranger's other spells. The Mark for Death ability is slightly lower damage than Hunter's Mark when first picked up, but is more versatile, and later scales as the ranger increases in level. This can make the ranger a very powerful combatant.

@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class-features.Item.tCmJrYx7G0AB0JZu]{Primeval Awareness} now functions similarly to @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-spells.Item.lwtpOJ9KoOjbFkNX]{Locate Creature} and costs a spell slot, with extra bonuses if the creature is too far to be located.

Rangers gain a &reference[climbing]{Climbing} and &reference[swimming]{Swimming} speed, and a movement bonus, at level 7.

@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.kAIu9pIhIScWpb3U]{Hunters} are more offensively focused, and have a third attack as part of the attack action instead of their old multiattack.

@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class.Item.RTS23KqJMFWlzLKd]{Rogue}

We made the damage on rogues more reliable at the cost of some survivability, and made minor edits to everything. The largest change we made was adding @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class-features.Item.mPbCg9EwNYa7Z7Lo]{Extra Attack} and several alternate options for sneak attacks. These alternate sneak attack options cause conditions and secondary effects at the cost of some damage upon successfully sneak attacking a creature.

We changed @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class-features.Item.8Ctt1vOsZuKXxAIN]{sneak attack} so that you could trigger sneak attack even if you had disadvantage on the attack roll, as long as you had a creature hostile to your target within 5 ft. of the target. This was so that effects like the &Reference[poisoned] or &Reference[blinded] condition would not nullify the rogue's ability to do significant damage entirely, potentially for entire combat encounters or longer.

We also moved @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class-features.Item.oazyHMo51SRvTJe5]{Uncanny Dodge} from level 5 to 15, since rogues at level 5 were inexplicably some of the hardiest characters.

We added @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class-features.Item.mPbCg9EwNYa7Z7Lo]{Extra Attack} to rogues at level 5, a substantial increase in damage and reliability of sneak attack. This also helps remove the strong incentive for rogues to dual-wield, since now all rogues of level 5 or higher will have more than one chance to trigger sneak attack, which means the off-hand attack from dual wielding is no longer crucial for reliable damage.

We changed the level at which rogues get most of their features to allow rogues to get their second archetype feature at level 6, as well as getting most of their important features a bit earlier.

We removed the rogue's Ability Score Improvement at level 10.

We improved the rogue's @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class-features.Item.mWzkmsjC9Vq9nLHD]{Blindsight} and @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class-features.Item.CS8446NSrWP8XtEs]{Stroke of Luck} abilities.

@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.2nzGa7qPoj6lZvFi]{Thieves} are mostly unrecognizable from their original version. They are the only rogues to get Uncanny Dodge, and most of their abilities focus around movement, directing attacks into your enemies, and using your Cunning Action more than other rogues.

@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class.Item.emEIZZAh0s8Ed62c]{Sorcerer}

The biggest changes to the sorcerer class revolve around @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class-features.Item.zH8SvVHZWJOkh0jB]{metamagic}.

We added two metamagic options to flesh out the list from baseline 5e rules, gave sorcerers two more metamagic options to their total number, made them get new metamagic options and sorcerous origin features at lower levels than before, and made it so they recover up to half their sorcery point total on a short rest.

The worst metamagic options are improved.

We also gave them @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class-features.Item.3bxCkcMt5FOEpPSg]{a feature} at level 9 that allows them to bolster their wisdom saves for high level play.

We created @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class-features.Item.xIFx0QonSkUeGqYS]{a new capstone feature} to replace their old one, which we replaced by allowing level 2 and higher sorcerers to regain sorcery points on a short rest.

In baseline 5e, sorcery points could be abused to create an unlimited number of spell slots for certain multiclass characters. Our rules here prevent that: sorcerers can no longer create more spell slots on top of their usual maximum.

There's also a few minor tweaks here and there.

@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.BbYFmYfkCBVVmIox]{Draconic} sorcerers are similar in flavor as before, but gain a breath weapon and a more targeted frightening ability they can use as a bonus action.

@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class.Item.whbTNYgkqWV8oGt3]{Warlock}

We improved the spellcasting ability of warlocks and switched them to a long rest recovery system, as well as improved, simplified, and streamlined many features.

@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class-features.Item.FHiTJvr5Nbb7HsgX]{Eldritch Blast} is no longer a cantrip, but a class feature that scales to warlock level. It also add the warlock's charisma modifier to damage by default, rather than requiring the Agonizing Blast invocation.

Overhauled @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class-features.Item.KsxDfyMKg8CPrOR5]{spellcasting for warlocks}. The baseline 5e warlock regained all spell slots of up to 5th level when they finished a short rest. However, these warlocks also only have 2 spell slots until level 11. They also always casted spells at the highest level slot (up to 5th), rendering many lower level spells obsolete. By giving warlocks more spell slots of varying levels and having them restore on a long rest, the warlock has more versatility and can choose how to expend their resources without worrying about when a short rest will next come. In baseline 5e rules, warlocks gain Mystic Arcanum spells at levels 11, 13, 15, and 17. These Mystic Arcanum spells were meant to give warlocks 6th level spell slots and higher that they regained on a long rest, as opposed to all their other spells, which they recovered on a short rest. However, because our Reawakened Warlock regains ALL spell slots on a long rest, Mystic Arcanum spell slots could be combined with the main spellcasting system, which meant there was no need for these spells to have their own system.

@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class-features.Item.Iu9m4NqscIi7sOpE]{Pact of the Chain} familiars are now more powerful and have dedicated invocations to improve them.

@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class-features.Item.QfgyRthZkHYTXO0I]{Pact of the Warrior} replaced Pact of the Blade, and synergizes well with the new @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class-features.Item.c1lEKIaiHk8rQNMa]{Eldritch Weapon} invocation, which allows any warlock to use their charisma as their ability score for all weapons.

@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class-features.Item.bduOoPYhwMQljlUs]{Pact of the Tome} now allows warlocks to regain some spell slots on a short rest, similar to the wizard.

A few invocations were renamed for Elkan 5e. Beguiling Influence is now called @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class-features.Item.SlPIFktiO9SAzs7S]{Enchantment of Aptitude}, and it now gives you a choice of any two skills instead of just persuasion and deception. Book of Ancient Secrets was renamed to @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class-features.Item.vINGSaFuXG5d8FhS]{Book of Rituals} so that it wouldn't be confused with the new @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class-features.Item.Eoy9E4sb8gMSxi03]{Book of Magical Secrets}.

@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.2Ji9iuEL6e6jTSvQ]{&reference[fiend]} warlocks are mostly the same. Their @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class-features.Item.O1owFjLB6wfrqs0J]{Dark One's Blessing} cannot give more temporary hit points than your victim had as their hit point maximum, eliminating the 'bag of rats' strategy. Normally we wouldn't even note something like that, but the subclass is barely changed.

@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-class.Item.qM0tUqAZW3V8L4pF]{Wizard}

We made a few changes to wizards to make them more flexible and be more varied.

Wizard subclasses give access to all spells of a given school.

In the Elkan 5e wizard, wizards learn as many spells as before, and cannot scribe scrolls to increase that number. However, all spells in their spellbook are prepared at all times. We removed scribing scrolls to equalize wizards a bit with other casters so that they would be just as good in low magic and high magic settings, improving the consistency of balance. Also, because we allowed wizards to have all their spells prepared at all times, we couldn't let them get a number of prepared spells in the hundreds. We decided this was a good trade off, because the already large number of spells wizards could learn meant that having more prepared at once was more important than having more options to switch to at a rest. Previously, wizards only had about half their spells available for use on average. Additionally, the availability of magic scrolls would vary by game table, so wizards became the only casters to rely on gold and magic items to expand their spell list. Additionally, wizards would likely get all the spells they wanted on level up anyway, with any additional spells being random and sometimes not suited to their playstyle.

We added the Expertise feature at level 2 to allow wizards to keep up with rogues and bards when it came to specialized skills, especially in cases like with the Arcana skill.

Wizards get the arcana skill as a bonus skill.

@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.IdDGr2dN95mq2yjj]{Evokers} had their abilities cleaned up and streamlined a bit. Their abilities now add damage on non-evocation spells.

New Subclasses

Here are the new subclasses we've created for Elkan 5e:

Barbarian (@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.LzO80qqU06DveffI]{Bloodrager}): a spellcasting barbarian that gains spells from a sorcerous origin. Deals damage to those who attack them and deals damage according to the origin chosen. Has a variant that triggers wild surges.

Bard (@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.8q8sBu45Sj0d6SeM]{Cacophony}): a bard focused on blasting things with sonic damage. They gain some utility around silence and their senses.

Bard (@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.YlUIIUF2CyTVJMNL]{Jester}): a bard focused on using bardic inspiration as a debuff for enemies rather than buffing allies. They gain a powerful version of Vicious Mockery, and gain abilities that set enemies against targets of their choice and do psychic damage to those they debuff.

Bard (@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.wKTvSF8ABlb2BeuS]{Warchanter}): a martial-oriented bard that fights with weapons and boosts weapon attacks for allies.

Cleric (@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.jZoZeTGtCmvkDVlD]{Death}): a cleric that deals increased necrotic damage and leeches life from foes and allies alike to empower their allies.

Druid @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.F09ANo5m0ab4NP3K]{(Grassland):} a druid that increases the speed of the party and allows allies to ram into opponents for extra damage.

Druid @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.8WooMnTS9C6TxzL6]{(Mountain):} a defensively-oriented druid that shields allies, as well as pushing enemies around.

Druid (@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.zcOFbSrLq7Npn6QD]{Shifter}): a druid that has powerful shapeshifting, similar to old shape-shifting subclasses, but less focused on sustaining damage and more focused on spellcasting while shifted and switching between forms.

Druid @UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.SJqMwue6OWMA5h34]{(Underworld):} a druid that influences the perception of allies and foes, dealing psychic damage and getting into the heads of those who oppose them.

Fighter (@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.P8MIHUtdsVp3mtnX]{Bulwark}): a fighter with powerful defensive abilities that allow them to protect their party members.

Fighter (@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.jz9XffzV61BZQp7S]{Commander}): a support-oriented fighter that gives powerful buffs to party members, especially other martial characters who the commander can grant extra attacks to.

Fighter (@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.yHHwqD7r32bVXSUQ]{Spellsword}): a new spellcasting fighter that picks from any of the full caster classes to gain spells. They can channel their spells into their attacks and boast more utility than other fighters.

Monk (@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.9xK08kawH65jWXNx]{Elementalist}): a monk that switches between &reference[elemental] stances, makes ranged strikes with &reference[elemental] damage, and casts spells.

Monk (@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.wbxMlrL38E9Tfewu]{Shadowdancer}): a monk with the ability to turn invisible, cast some utility spells, and move around in shadows.

Paladin (@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.dgKnRK0uMsAXk1XK]{Avenger}): an offensively-focused paladin that punishes foes and forces them to fight.

Ranger (@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.tEkCUpI1OFUxTOi2]{Beastmaster}): a ranger with an animal companion that scales to their level and fights in tandem with the ranger.

Ranger (@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.QDfjPuD9no0Lk7vo]{Spellbreaker}): a ranger with an animal companion that scales to their level and fights in tandem with the ranger.

Rogue (@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.SSo5zQSshx3ED7wN]{Assassin}): a rogue that focuses on acting before their opponents, striking quickly, and dealing extra damage to finish off targets with low hit points.

Rogue (@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.oEndiYznMjaUBZrD]{Brute}): a tough martial-focused rogue that grapples targets and knocks them prone, overwhelming and disabling their foes.

Rogue (@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.uj9mpW7cz3h3yrXx]{Duelist}): a melee-focused rogue that can reroll attacks and move quickly and unhindered through a battlefield.

Rogue (@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.8H0DO72vcXDNC271]{Mystic Trickster}): a spellcasting rogue that picks from any of the full caster classes to gain spells. They can sneak attack with cantrips and later spells, and boast more utility than other rogues.

Sorcerer (@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.PWqruY6JIMfie0Tp]{Air}/@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.1n6J4stvs96zxnji]{Earth}/@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.mF63eSPEfls2vYlg]{Fire}/@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.zAd9Wo5c2aOqPO8j]{Water Savants}): Elementally attuned sorcerers who deal increased damage with spells from their chosen element. &reference[elemental] savants eventually take on aspects of their chosen element as well.

Sorcerer (@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.vKEThfA1dQ17GXxI]{Wild Mage}): Chaotic spellcasters who trigger random magical effects with their spells called wild surges. An Elkan 5e favorite.

Warlock (@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.uGl6fwKyiq2UXTVZ]{&reference[celestial]}): A simple subclass that focuses on blasting enemies with radiant energy and healing allies, especially at the brink of death.

Warlock (@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.1ZQxVoZ1dbGVuP9Q]{&reference[fey]}): Warlocks who focus on misdirection, trickery, and manipulation. Can switch places with enemies to cause them to take damage instead of themselves.

Wizard (@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.vGtqUSmHasAoBCxk]{Illusionist}): Masters of magical deception, illusionists can bolster normally harmless illusions to the point they can actually harm people.

Wizard (@UUID[Compendium.elkan5e.elkan5e-subclass.Item.wJXoSIzImQPAjnkm]{Necromancer}): These wizards toy with magics of life and death, and are accompanied by a Graveguard, a powerful &reference[undead] servant who draws upon their master's strength.
